coauthors.name: Aharon N. Varady (digital imaging and document preparation)
coauthors.bio: Aharon Varady, founding director of the Open Siddur Project, is a copyright researcher and amateur book scanner. He prepares digital images and new digital editions of prayer books and related works in the Public Domain in order to make their constituent parts (prayers, translations, annotations, etc.) publicly accessible for collaborative transcription by project volunteers. (In some cases, he finds existing digital editions prepared by others that require correction and reformatting.) If you appreciate his efforts, please send him a kind note or contribute to his patreon account.

coauthors.name: Marcos Edery (translation)
coauthors.bio: Rabbi Mordechai Marcos Edery (1928-2010), born in Tangier, Spanish Morocco, was a traditionalist Conservative movement rabbi in Argentina, Jewish educator throughout Latin  America, and translator. He studied at the Maimonides Seminary in Tangier, going to Israel in the 1950s to work in teaching institutes for graduates arriving from the Diaspora. In 1956 he was invited to Buenos Aires to serve as Director of the Majon le Limudei Haiaadut of the Israelite Congregation of the Argentine Republic. In 1960 he attended Camp Ramah in Laguna de los Padres as a visiting professor. In Buenos Aires, Rabbi Edery became close with the Conservative movement rabbi Marshall Meyer, working in the Chalom Community in the Colegiales neighborhood. At the same time, he was appointed vice-rector of the Latin American Rabbinical Seminary and director of the Michlal√° Hibrit in Buenos Aires, affiliated with AMIA (Association of Jewish Families). At the request of the World Council of Synagogues, Rabbi Edery translated into Spanish the Siddur and the Ma·∏•zor for Rosh Hashanah and Yom Kippur in both Ashkenazi and Sefaradi nus·∏•aot, with notes and commentaries by Rabbi Meyer. In the early 1970s, he became rabbi of the Bet El Community, sharing the pulpit with Rabbi Meyer, a position he retired from more than a decade later, returning to a more traditional form of halakhic observance. As rabbi of Bet El and vice-rector of the Latin American Rabbinical Seminary, he began a translation of the Torah portions and their corresponding haftarot, for both the Ashkenazi and Sephardi rites, with his own commentaries based on the exegeses of traditional parshanim (commentators): Rashi, Ibn Ezra, Rambam, Ramban, Abarbanel, among others. The first volume, Bereshit, was published in 1982. Having completed this monumental work, he translated the book of ·∏≤ohelet on the same basis. In 1985, he founded Congregation Tora ve Jaim, creating a new synagogue alternative in the vast Buenos Aires area.

Meyer (March 25, 1930 ‚Äì December 29, 1993), born in Brooklyn, New York, was a Conservative movement rabbi who became a recognized international human rights activist while living and working in Argentina from 1958 to 1984, during the period of the "Dirty War" in the 1970s. He was elected by president Ra√∫l Alfons√≠n to be one of the members of the National Commission on the Disappearance of Persons. After the restoration of democracy in 1983, Meyer was awarded the nation's highest honor, the Order of the Liberator General San Mart√≠n, by the new president. In Argentina Meyer also led the congregation Comunidad Bet El and founded Seminario Rab√≠nico Latinoamericano, a Conservative Jewish rabbinical school in Buenos Aires that has trained generations of Spanish-speaking rabbis. Rabbi Meyer returned to the United States in 1984 and that year became rabbi of Congregation Bnai Jeshurun in New York City. He was called to revive the congregation of the oldest Ashkenazi synagogue in the city. He was one of those honored by president Cristina Fern√°ndez de Kirchner to those who fought for the restoration of democracy in Argentina

coauthors.name: Masorti Olami
coauthors.bio: Masorti Olami (also known as the World Council of Synagogues) is the international umbrella organization for Masorti Judaism, founded in 1957 with the goal of making Masorti Judaism a force in the Jewish world. Masorti Olami is affiliated with communities in over 36 countries, representing with partners in Israel and North America close to two million people worldwide, both registered members and non-member identifiers. Masorti Olami builds, renews, and strengthens Jewish life throughout the world, with efforts that focus on existing and developing communities in Europe, Latin America, the former Soviet Union, Africa, Asia, and Australia. All of Masorti Olami's activities are conducted within the context of the overall Conservative Judaism movement, in close cooperation with its affiliated organizations in North America and Israel.

◊û◊ó◊ñ◊ï◊® ◊ú◊®◊ê◊© ◊î◊©◊†◊î Majzor para Rosh haShanah (1968) is a bilingual Hebrew-Spanish prayerbook for Rosh haShanah compiled and translated by Rabbi Marcos Edery z”l, and published by the World Council of [Conservative/Masorti] Synagogues under the supervision of Rabbi Marshall T. Meyer (1930-1993). Earlier prayerbooks represented the Ashkenazi liturgical tradition. This is the first siddur that we are aware of for Sepharadi congreations in the Conservative movement. The Hebrew is based primarily on the S&P siddurim compiled and translated by Rabbi Dr. Savid de Sola Pool. Besides the liturgy (in the Ashkenazi nusa·∏•), the prayerbook is prefaced by Seli·∏•ot and includes essays concerning prayer by 20th century scholars in Spanish translation.

This work is in the Public Domain in the United States by treaty according the Uruguay Round Agreements Act (1994), 50 years having passed since its publication in Argentina (the general term of copyright for works published between 1957 and 1997).

Source (Translation) Translation (English)
NOTA DEL TRADUCTOR
TRANSLATOR’S NOTE
Este Majzor para Rosh Hashan√°, es presentado con la firme esperanza de que pueda satisfacer las necesidades e inquietudes espirituales de todas aquellas personas que est√°n empe√±adas en una lucha ardua e ingrata, tratando de perpetuar los valores del Juda√≠smo tradicional en sus m√°s dignas costumbres y tradiciones. Asimismo es un intento de llevar nuestras oraciones ‚Äîalgunas de ellas varias veces milenarias‚Äî, desde la cima de su aspecto literario al valle de lo comprensible. Especialmente para tratar de ofrecer a nuestros j√≥venes, una versi√≥n contempor√°nea de las l√°grimas y alegr√≠as, de la angustia y del regocijo, que nuestros antecesores tradujeron en Salmos, Himnos, poes√≠as y oraciones.
This Ma·∏•zor for Rosh Hashanah is presented with the firm hope that it will satisfy the spiritual needs and concerns of all those who are engaged in an arduous and thankless struggle, trying to perpetuate the values of traditional Judaism in its most dignified customs and traditions. It is also an attempt to bring our prayers‚Äîsome of them thousands of years old‚Äîfrom the heights of their literary form to the valley of comprehensibility. Especially to try to offer our young people a contemporary version of the tears and joys, the anguish and rejoicing, that our ancestors translated into Psalms, Hymns, poems, and prayers.
Pero sabemos que uno de los problemas m√°s escabrosos para el juda√≠smo contempor√°neo, es el lograr una s√≠ntesis entre lo antiguo y lo m√°s nuevo de la tradici√≥n jud√≠a. Pedimos a Ds., que este Majzor pueda ser nuestro modesto aporte para el logro o consecuci√≥n de tan noble fin, en cuanto al campo de la liturgia respecta.
But we know that one of the most difficult problems for contemporary Judaism is achieving a synthesis between the ancient and the newest aspects of Jewish tradition. We ask God that this Ma·∏•zor may be our modest contribution to the achievement or attainment of such a noble goal, as far as the field of liturgy is concerned.
Es bien conocida la opini√≥n de los sabios del Talmud que dijeron: ‚ÄúTodo aqu√©l que traduce un vers√≠culo literalmente ha cometido un fraude‚Äù. (Kidushin, 49a.)
The opinion of the sages of the Talmud is well known: ‚ÄúAnyone who translates a verse literally has committed fraud.‚Äù (Kidushin 49a.)
El lector conocedor de los textos del Majzor seguramente ya vislumbra, que si esta opini√≥n talm√∫dica de por s√≠ autorizada, ha de ser tenida en cuenta, pr√°cticamente ser√≠a imposible traducir un Majzor con su numerosos ‚ÄúPiutim‚Äù, a ning√∫n idioma del mundo contempor√°neo.
Readers familiar with the texts of the Ma·∏•zor will surely already realize that if this authoritative Talmudic opinion is to be taken into account, it would be practically impossible to translate a Ma·∏•zor with its numerous ‚ÄúPiyutim‚Äù into any contemporary language.
Por eso hemos abordado la tarea de verter el Majzor al idioma castellano guiados por tres principios fundamentales, a saber:
That is why we have undertaken the task of translating the Ma·∏•zor into Spanish, guided by three fundamental principles, namely:
a) El principio de la continuidad con la tradici√≥n lit√∫rgica. Esta consideraci√≥n, si bien no nos exime de la obligaci√≥n de actualizar las formas devocionales, nos previene de no incurrir en desestima de las creaciones del esp√≠ritu, producto de la piedad de las generaciones pasadas.
a) The principle of continuity with liturgical tradition. This consideration, while not exempting us from the obligation to update devotional forms, warns us against disregarding the creations of the spirit, which are the product of the piety of past generations.
El hecho mismo de mantener una continuidad lit√∫rgica puede encaminarnos a una creaci√≥n constante y revitalizadora en ese terreno.
The very fact of maintaining liturgical continuity can lead us to constant and revitalizing creation in this area.
Pues, generalmente, cuando leemos las creaciones milenarias del Majzor y pasa ante nuestros ojos el aporte sucesivo de las generaciones, no podemos ocultar nuestra nostalgia hacia ese don de la creatividad religiosa, de la cual nuestra generaci√≥n sufre una carencia aguda.
Well, generally, when we read the ancient creations of the Ma·∏•zor and see the successive contributions of generations before our eyes, we cannot hide our nostalgia for that gift of religious creativity, which our generation sorely lacks.
b) El principio de sensibilidad hacia las necesidades espirituales de nuestra generaci√≥n.
b) The principle of sensitivity to the spiritual needs of our generation.
Un Majzor como libro de oraciones debe expresar tambi√©n nuestras propias aspiraciones e inquietudes. Por eso hemos insertado en el mismo, escritos salidos de las plumas de los mejores pensadores jud√≠os modernos y contempor√°neos, ya que creemos que ellos reflejan las inquietudes espirituales del jud√≠o del siglo ‚Ö©‚Ö©.
A Ma·∏•zor as a prayer book should also express our own aspirations and concerns. That is why we have included writings from the pens of the best modern and contemporary Jewish thinkers, as we believe that they reflect the spiritual concerns of Jews in the 20th century.
Es sabido que los textos del Majzor representan el ‚ÄúMatb√©a shel Tefil√°‚Äù o sea la expresi√≥n del m√≠nimo de nuestra potencialidad devocional, por eso las generaciones tienen el deber de un constante aporte al mismo.
It is well known that the texts of the Ma·∏•zor represent the ‚ÄúMatb√©ah shel Tefil√°h,‚Äù that is, the expression of the minimum of our devotional potential, which is why generations have a duty to contribute to it constantly.
Teniendo en cuenta la sensibilidad arriba mencionada, nos hemos permitido hacer una traducci√≥n, no literal de los textos hebreos, aunque si firmemente fiel al esp√≠ritu de los mismos. Nos preguntamos al respecto, ¬øes acaso leg√≠timo el apartarse del texto, ofrecer una traducci√≥n libre del mismo?
Taking into account the sensitivity mentioned above, we have taken the liberty of producing a translation that is not literal from the Hebrew texts, although it is firmly faithful to their spirit. We ask ourselves, is it legitimate to depart from the text and offer a free translation of it?
Nuestra respuesta es la misma que enunciaron los sabios del Talmud, cuando dijeron: ‚ÄúTodo aqu√©l que traduce un vers√≠culo literalmente, ha cometido un fraude‚Äù (Kidushin 49a).
Our answer is the same as that given by the sages of the Talmud, when they said: ‚ÄúAnyone who translates a verse literally has committed fraud‚Äù (Kidushin 49a).
Cada idioma tiene su forma distintiva y peculiar, por eso si insistimos en retener el sentido literal del mismo llegaremos a lo absurdo o sea la distorsi√≥n literaria.
Each language has its own distinctive and peculiar form, so if we insist on retaining its literal meaning, we will end up with absurdity, or literary distortion.
A modo de ilustraci√≥n, nos permitimos citar aqu√≠ un estilo literario b√≠blico llamado en hebreo ‚ÄúKefel hainian bemilim shonot‚Äù o sea, un paralelismo en la poes√≠a que enuncia, en un mismo vers√≠culo, dos veces la misma idea con palabras distintas.
By way of illustration, we would like to mention here a biblical literary style called in Hebrew ‚ÄúKefel hainian bemilim shonot,‚Äù that is, a parallelism in poetry that expresses the same idea twice in the same verse using different words.
Ese estilo es uno de los m√°s apreciados por el lector de la Biblia en su idioma original, no as√≠ para el lector de la misma en castellano.
This style is one of the most appreciated by readers of the Bible in its original language, but not by readers of the Spanish translation.
Si tenemos en cuenta tambi√©n que el objeto de esta traducci√≥n es el alentar al piadoso que no conoce el idioma de la Biblia a orar en su propio idioma, comprenderemos la necesidad imperiosa que tenemos de una traducci√≥n no literal.
If we also consider that the purpose of this translation is to encourage the devout who do not know the language of the Bible to pray in their own language, we will understand the urgent need for a non-literal translation.
La oraci√≥n en un idioma no hebreo, para el hombre que no entiende este √∫ltimo, ha sido el objeto de una pronunciaci√≥n manifiesta de nuestros sabios, desde la √©poca de la Mishn√°, pasando por la Guemar√° y llegando hasta el Rambam y el ‚ÄúShuljan Aruj‚Äù.
Prayer in a language other than Hebrew, for those who do not understand the latter, has been the subject of explicit pronouncements by our sages, from the time of the Mishnah, through the Gemara, and up to the Rambam and the Shul·∏•an Arukh.
As√≠ podemos leer en la Mishn√°, Tratado Sot√°, cap. 7, mishn√° 1: ‚ÄúEstas son las oraciones que se pueden pronunciar en cualquier idioma… la lectura de la Shem√°, la Amid√°, la Bendici√≥n despu√©s de las comidas…‚Äù Haci√©ndose eco de esta mishn√°, Maim√≥nides en su libro ‚ÄúMishn√© Tor√°‚Äù dice literalmente: ‚ÄúLa persona puede leer la Keriat-Shem√° en cualquier idioma que la entienda (Hiljot Keriat Shem√°, cap. 2, halaj√° 10).
Thus we read in the Mishnah, Tractate Sotah, chapter 7, Mishnah 1: ‚ÄúThese are the prayers that may be recited in any language… the reading of the Shema, the Amidah, the blessing after meals…‚Äù Echoing this Mishnah, Maimonides in his book Mishneh Torah says literally: “A person may read the ·∏≤eriat Shema in any language he understands (Hiljot Keriat Shema, chap. 2, halakhah 10).
Finalmente, esta opini√≥n fue codificada con car√°cter de ‚Äúhalaj√°‚Äù por el autor del ‚ÄúShuljan Aruj‚Äù, Rabi Iosef Karo. As√≠ leemos en el ‚ÄúOraj Jaim‚Äù, cap. 62, con respecto a Keriat Shema, y en el cap. 101 con respecto a la Amid√°.
Finally, this opinion was codified as halakhah by the author of the Shul·∏•an Arukh, Rabbi Yosef Karo. We read this in Ora·∏• ·∏§aim, chapter 62, regarding ·∏≤eriat Shema, and in chapter 101 regarding the Amidah.
c) Integridad intelectual. Este punto requiere de nosotros dos cosas al mismo tiempo, a saber: no traicionar conceptos emitidos por el autor y no evadir el problema de la actualizaci√≥n de los valores tradicionales m√°s antiguos.
c) Intellectual integrity. This point requires two things from us at the same time, namely: not betraying the concepts put forward by the author and not evading the problem of updating the oldest traditional values.
Para ellos hemos recurrido a la ‚Äúfuerza interpretativa‚Äù de nuestros ex√©getas. Cada texto, cada cap√≠tulo de la Biblia, cada mishn√°, han sido traducidos en base a la ex√©gesis de los mismos.
For them, we have resorted to the ‚Äúinterpretive power‚Äù of our exegetes. Each text, each chapter of the Bible, each Mishnah, has been translated based on their exegesis.
Sirva de ejemplo ilustrativo el vers√≠culo siguiente del Salmo 29, ‚ÄúKol A’ iejolel aialot‚Äù; generalmente, este vers√≠culo ha sido traducido: ‚ÄúLa voz de A’ causa dolor (de parto) a las gacelas‚Äù. Las √∫ltimas investigaciones del idioma b√≠blico y su estilo, as√≠ como el contexto, demuestran que esta traducci√≥n no es la mejor. Por eso lo hemos traducido: ‚ÄúLa voz de Ds. hizo danzar a los √°rboles‚Äù ya que eso se confirma por la segunda parte del vers√≠culo que dice: ‚ÄúVaiejesof iearot‚Äù o sea: ‚Äú√âl deshoj√≥ los bosques‚Äù. Adem√°s seg√∫n el contexto veremos que el tema central del Salmo es: La voz de Ds., y su efecto sobre la naturaleza.
The following verse from Psalms 29 serves as an illustrative example: ‚ÄúKol Adonai ye·∏•olel ayalot‚Äú; generally, this verse has been translated as: ‚ÄùThe voice of Adonai causes pain (of childbirth) to the gazelles.” The latest research on biblical language and style, as well as context, shows that this translation is not the best. That is why we have translated it as: ‚ÄúThe voice of God made the trees dance,‚Äù as this is confirmed by the second part of the verse, which says: ‚ÄúVa-ye·∏•esof ye’arot,‚Äù meaning ‚ÄúHe stripped the forests bare.‚Äù Furthermore, according to the context, we see that the central theme of the Psalm is: The voice of God and its effect on nature.
A veces, el lector notar√° que un mismo t√©rmino, o una misma oraci√≥n ha sido traducida en forma distinta en lugares distintos del Majzor. Por ejemplo, en lo que respecta a ‚ÄúTejiat hametim‚Äù. En la Amid√°, traducimos: ‚Äútraer√°s a los difuntos a la vida inmortal‚Äù; mientras que en el himno ‚ÄúIgdal‚Äù traducimos ‚ÄúCon su misericordia revivir√° a los muertos‚Äù.
Sometimes, the reader will notice that the same term or sentence has been translated differently in different places in the Ma·∏•zor. For example, with regard to ‚ÄúTe·∏•iat hametim.‚Äù In the Amidah, we translate it as ‚Äúyou will bring the dead to immortal life,‚Äù while in the ‚ÄòYigdal‚Äô hymn we translate it as ‚Äúwith his mercy he will revive the dead.‚Äù
Con ello hemos querido ofrecer al lector una posibilidad de interpretaci√≥n de dicho concepto, extra√≠da del mundo del pensamiento jud√≠o, guardando, no obstante, tambi√©n el significado literal del mismo.
With this, we wanted to offer the reader a possible interpretation of this concept, drawn from the world of Jewish thought, while also preserving its literal meaning.
En cuanto a los ‚ÄúPiutim‚Äù de los famosos poetas como: Iehuda Halevi, Mois√©s Ibn-Ezra, Shelomo Ibn-Gabirol y otros, hemos preferido tener a la vista las ediciones cient√≠ficas de los mismos, como lo es la del profesor Shirman, de la Universidad Hebrea de Jerusalem. Es por eso que a veces el lector notar√° que la traducci√≥n se desv√≠a ligeramente de los textos tradicionales del Majzor, para tener en cuenta las versiones autorizadamente corregidas en base a manuscritos y otros trabajos de investigaci√≥n.
As for the ‚ÄúPiyutim‚Äù of famous poets such as Yehuda Halevi, Moses Ibn Ezra, Shelomo Ibn Gabirol, and others, we have preferred to refer to scholarly editions of these works, such as that of Professor Shirman of the Hebrew University of Jerusalem. This is why the reader will sometimes notice that the translation deviates slightly from the traditional texts of the Ma·∏•zor, in order to take into account the authoritatively corrected versions based on manuscripts and other research works.
A modo de ilustraci√≥n, en el Piut, ‚ÄúAjot Ketan√°‚Äù (p√°g. 68), leemos en el texto tradicional: ‚ÄúVehi queforajat aleta nitsa, lo hivshilu ashkeloteha‚Äù, mientras que las ediciones corregidas de ese ‚ÄúPiut‚Äù sugieren ‚ÄúVehi keforajat aleta nitsa, ki hivshilu ashkeloteha‚Äù, lo que permite una mejor comprensi√≥n del contexto general. Por eso rogamos al estimado lector que trate de comprender esta tendencia nuestra cuando el caso lo requiera.
By way of illustration, in the piyut, ‚ÄúA·∏•ot ·∏≤etanah‚Äù (p. 68), we read in the traditional text: ‚ÄúVehi ·∏≥efora·∏•at al’ta nitsa, lo hivshilu ashkeloteha,‚Äù while the corrected editions of that ‚ÄòPiut‚Äô suggest ‚ÄúVehi keforajat aleta nitsa, ki hivshilu ashkelotehah,‚Äù which allows for a better understanding of the general context. We therefore ask our esteemed readers to try to understand our tendency to do so when the case requires it.
En el orden t√©cnico de las cosas, y en nuestro af√°n de hacer participar a toda la Congregaci√≥n en las oraciones, hemos insertado en el texto castellano una transcripci√≥n fon√©tica de los pasajes lit√∫rgicos m√°s cl√°sicos, con el fin de llegar hasta aquellas personas que a√∫n no pueden leer el idioma de la Biblia.
In the technical order of things, and in our desire to involve the entire Congregation in prayer, we have inserted a phonetic transcription of the most classic liturgical passages into the Spanish text, in order to reach those who are not yet able to read the language of the Bible.
En otro orden de cosas este Majzor, pudo ser una realidad gracias a la buena voluntad, ayuda y sensibilidad, de muchos amigos y hombres de bien.
On another note, this Ma·∏•zor was made possible thanks to the goodwill, help, and sensitivity of many friends and good people.
En primer lugar citaremos a la Uni√≥n de Congregaciones Sefaraditas de los Estados Unidos, que gentilmente nos autoriz√≥ a hacer uso de los grabados de la versi√≥n hebrea del Majzor por ella publicado en la ciudad de New York, en el a√±o 1937. Esa edici√≥n se debi√≥ al trabajo de compilaci√≥n del Rabino David de Sola Pool, de la Congregaci√≥n ‚ÄúShearith Israel‚Äù, fiel exponente de las mejores tradiciones lit√∫rgicas del juda√≠smo hispano-portugu√©s.
First, we would like to mention the Union of Sephardic Congregations of the United States, which kindly authorized us to use the engravings from the Hebrew version of the Machzor published by them in New York City in 1937. That edition was the result of the compilation work of Rabbi David de Sola Pool, of the Congregation Shearith Israel, a faithful exponent of the best liturgical traditions of Spanish-Portuguese Judaism.
La comisi√≥n directiva de la Sinagoga ‚ÄúChalom‚Äù ha sido un factor determinante en la decisi√≥n de llevar adelante este proyecto. A todos sus miembros tambi√©n van nuestros m√°s c√°lidos agradecimientos. Igualmente agradecemos al Consejo Mundial de Sinagogas, al Seminario Rab√≠nico Latinoamericano, a su comisi√≥n directiva y, especialmente, a su director Rabino Marshall T. Meyer, por los ingentes esfuerzos de toda √≠ndole que nos permitieron lanzar esta nuestra primera edici√≥n. Un sentimiento de gratitud y de agradecimiento para el personal de: Macagno, Landa y C√≠a., especialmente para el se√±or Emilio Montagnoli, colaborador de inestimable ayuda para un trabajo tan arduo como es el de una edici√≥n biling√ºe.
The board of directors of the “Shalom” Synagogue has been a decisive factor in the decision to move forward with this project. We extend our warmest thanks to all its members. We also thank the World Council of Synagogues, the Latin American Rabbinical Seminary, its board of directors, and especially its director, Rabbi Marshall T. Meyer, for their tremendous efforts of all kinds that enabled us to launch this, our first edition. We are grateful to the staff of Macagno, Landa y C√≠a., especially Mr. Emilio Montagnoli, whose invaluable assistance was essential to the arduous task of producing a bilingual edition.
Finalmente, mis profundos agradecimientos a Shoshana, esposa y compa√±era de trabajo, que tuvo a su cargo la revisi√≥n de los manuscritos de la versi√≥n castellana.
Finally, my deepest thanks to Shoshana, my wife and co-worker, who was responsible for reviewing the manuscripts of the Spanish version.
Quiera el Todopoderoso bendecirlos a todos, prodig√°ndoles Su bendici√≥n de paz y prosperidad.
May the Almighty bless you all, showering you with His blessings of peace and prosperity.
Marcos EDERY
Buenos Aires, Tamuz 5728
Julio 1968
